Experiment configuration: python experiments.py --experiment_name run_diversity.py --n_trials 10 --mins_timeout 10 --language Dafny --problem_name problem_opt0_opt --seed 42 --base_model_name ./my_dpo_model

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false

  |

  |                                 ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. ```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

   |
10 |   case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
   |                                                 ^

ex.dfy(10,48): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1)
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2)
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt

   |

   |     ^

### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1)
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2)
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt

   |
18 |     var e2_opt := optimize(e2)
   |     ^

   |

   |     ^

   |
20 |     else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
   |                                           ^

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    var o2 := optimize(e2);

    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);

### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

   |
33 |     OptimizerOptimal(e2);
   |                          ^

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  case Add(e1, e2) =>

    var o2 := optimize(e2);

    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ => 
    // base case
}

### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

   |
22 |     else Add(o1, o2)
   |                     ^

ex.dfy(22,20): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

   |

   |              ^

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

   |
32 |     OptimizerOptimal(e2);
   |                          ^

ex.dfy(32,25): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>

   |
33 |   case _ =>
   |            ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

```dafny

  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

{

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  // base case
}
```

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then OptimizerOptimal(o2)

   |

   |                       ^

             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

    var o1 := optimize(e1);

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>

   |

   |            ^

             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

}

```dafny

             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
}

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
}

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1)

   |
17 |     var e1_opt := optimize(e1)
   |                               ^

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1)
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2)
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)

   |
21 |     else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
   |                             ^

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e

   |
22 |   case _ => e
   |              ^

ex.dfy(22,13): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

SCORE
1.0
['}\n', '}\n', '}\n', '}\n', '}\n']

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>

   |

   |            ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  }

  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e

    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);

    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt

  case _ => e

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

  {}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  {}
}
```

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {

   |
14 | function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
   |                                   ^

  | Var(name: string)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1)
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1)
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2)
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt

   |
18 |     var e2_opt := optimize(e2)
   |     ^

   |     ^

   |                                      ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1)
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2)
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt

   |
18 |     var e2_opt := optimize(e2)
   |     ^

ex.dfy(18,4): Error: semicolon expected
   |
19 |     if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
   |     ^

ex.dfy(19,4): Error: semicolon expected
   |
20 |     else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
   |                                           ^

ex.dfy(20,42): Error: else expected
3 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);

   |
17 |     var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
   |                                ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    var o2 := optimize(e2);

    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e

   |

   |          ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ => 
    // base case

   |
35 |     // base case
   |                 ^

ex.dfy(35,16): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['}\n', '}\n', '  {}\n', '    // base case\n', '    // base case\n']
TEXT

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ => 
    // base case

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ => 
    // base case
}
```

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny

  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false

  case _ => true

```dafny
// Define the ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Define the predicate `optimal`
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

// Define the optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1

   |
23 |     else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
   |                                   ^

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
// Define the ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Define the predicate `optimal`
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

// Define the optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

   |

   |                     ^

datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

// Define the optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: optimize preserves the optimal property
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
// Define the ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Define the predicate `optimal`
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

// Define the optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: optimize preserves the optimal property
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    // Recursively call the lemma on the sub-expressions
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ => ()
}

```dafny
// Define the ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Define the predicate `optimal`
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
// Define the ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Define the predicate `optimal`
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

// Define the optimizer function

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then
      OptimizerOptimal(e2)

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
// Define the ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Define the predicate `optimal`
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

// Define the optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: optimize preserves the optimal property
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    // Recursive case: optimize the sub-expressions
    var o1 := optimize(e1);

   |
35 |     var o1 := optimize(e1);
   |                            ^

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: optimize preserves the optimal property
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    // Recursive case: optimize the sub-expressions
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    // Call the lemma recursively
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
    // Base case: nothing to prove

   |
41 |     // Base case: nothing to prove
   |                                   ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
// Define the ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Define the predicate `optimal`
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

// Define the optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: optimize preserves the optimal property
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    // Recursive case: optimize the sub-expressions
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    // Call the lemma recursively
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
    // Base case: nothing to prove
}

['}\n', '}\n', '}\n', '}\n', '}\n']

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>

    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

```dafny
// Define the ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Define the predicate `optimal`
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

// Define the optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: optimize preserves the optimal property
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    // Recursive case: optimize the sub-expressions
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    // Call the lemma recursively
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
    // Base case: nothing to prove
}

  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
// Define the ADT for arithmetic expressions
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

// Define the predicate `optimal`
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

// Define the optimizer function
function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

// Lemma: optimize preserves the optimal property
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    // Recursive case: optimize the sub-expressions
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    // Call the lemma recursively
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
    // Base case: nothing to prove
}

}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny

             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>

   |                      ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

   |

   |                     ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);

   |

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then OptimizerOptimal(o2)

   |

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then OptimizerOptimal(o2)
    else if o2 == Const(0) then OptimizerOptimal(o1)

   |

   |                       ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition.   case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then OptimizerOptimal(o2)
    else if o2 == Const(0) then OptimizerOptimal(o1)
    else {

   |
31 |     if o1 == Const(0) then OptimizerOptimal(o2)
   |                       ^

ex.dfy(31,22): Error: lbrace expected

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then

   |

   |                       ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false

  case _ => true

CHOSEN SOLUTION
### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
}
```

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.
