### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  case _ => true

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1

   |

   |                                   ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

   |
20 |     else Add(o1, o2)
   |                     ^

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

   |
21 |   case _ => e
   |              ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then

   |
31 |     if o1 == Const(0) then
   |                       ^

ex.dfy(31,22): Error: lbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

None

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

case Foo(x, y) => 1

case _ => 3

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then OptimizerOptimal(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case _ => true

    var o1 := optimize(e1);

    else Add(o1, o2)

             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);

    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

    var o2 := optimize(e2);

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  {}
}

['}\n', '}\n', '}\n', '}\n', '}\n']

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  {}
}
```

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.

case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int)
             | Var(name: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  {}
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  |                 ^

  case _ => true

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>

    var o2 := optimize(e2);

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);

   |
29 |     OptimizerOptimal(e1);

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then OptimizerOptimal(e2)

   |
29 |     if o1 == Const(0) then OptimizerOptimal(e2)
   |                       ^

   |

   |                                                ^

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  {}
}

  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  {}
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  {}
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  {}
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {

  case Add(e1, e2) =>

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1)
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2)
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt

   |
15 |     var e2_opt := optimize(e2)
   |     ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false

  case _ => true

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2

    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

   |                          ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  {}

   |
32 |   {}
   |     ^

ex.dfy(32,4): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['}\n', '}\n', '  {}\n', '}\n', '}\n']

```dafny

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  {}
}
